title: TUC demands more progress on low pay, as jobless rate falls to just 6.2% - business live | Business | The Guardian
summary: european markets move higher - but uk misses out .
us inflation lower than expected , as prices fall 0.2 % in august .
tuc : real wage crisis must be fixed .
eurozone inflation rate revised up to +0.4 %
uk earnings rise , but real wages still falling .

documents.title: european markets move higher - but uk misses out
text: reports that the chinese central bank planned pump $ 81bn into the country 's top banks to boost the country 's economy , along with hopes of dovish comments from the us federal reserve about future interest rate rises helped to push european markets higher , writes nick fletcher .
the uk however slipped back , unsettled by the uncertainties of thursday 's vote on scottish independence .

the final scores showed : the ftse 100 finished 11.34 points or 0.17 % lower at 6780.90 germany 's dax added 0.3 % to 9661.50 france 's cac closed 0.5 % better at 4431.41 italy 's ftse mib added 1.55 % to 21,111.66 spain 's ibex ended 1.01 % better at 10,907.4 on wall street , ahead of the federal reserve announcement , the dow jones industrial average is up just 5 points or 0.03 % .
on that note , it 's time to close up for the evening .
thanks for all your comments .

the latest scottish referendum poll showing the no camp - slightly - in the lead but the yes vote gaining ground : stv news ( @ stvnews ) final ipsos-mori poll for @ twitterid : yes 49 % ( +7 ) no 51 % ( -7 ) # scotdecides steve collins ( @ tradedesk steve ) latest poll ( ipsos ) 49 % yes , 51 % no including the do n't knows .
dk around 5 % # scotland nicola duke ( @ nictrades ) that ipsos mori was due out tomorrow , released early

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: ok , time to recap .
the recovery in the uk 's labour market has continued , with the unemployment rate falling to its lowest level since the end of 2008 .
the uk jobless rate dropped to 6.2 % in the may-july quarter , down from 6.4 % last month .
the number of people in employment increased by 74,000 during the three months , to 30.61 million , while the number of unemployed people fell by 146,000 to 2.02 million .
and the claimant count , for august , fell below the one million mark for the first time since lehman brothers collapsed six years ago .
but real wages continue to lag inflation , with average earnings ( ex bonuses ) rising just 0.7 % annually .
uk real wages , to july 2014 union leaders warn that this wage squeeze can not continue , after years of falling real incomes .
tuc chief frances o'grady says : last week the governor of the bank of england said the fall in real wages is the worst since the 1920s and today 's figures show it getting worse .
pay increases are less than half the rate of inflation , so living standards keep on falling .
more people are working , but growth based on more low-paid jobs is n't working for britain .
we need jobs that ensure everyone gets a fair share in the growing economy through real increases to their wages . ''
government ministers took a more positive line , with prime minister david cameron hailing the remarkable '' progress made over the last year .
here are the key charts .

here 's larry elliott 's news story and analysis : wages will not rise until employers have to compete for talent uk unemployment rate lowest since 2008 crash elsewhere the pound has rallied ahead of tomorrow 's scottish referendum , after the latest polls showed a four-point lead for the no side .
that also pushed spanish bond yields down .
there 's mixed news on global inflation .
the eurozone is not as close to deflation as feared , after eurostat revised its data .
prices rose by 0.4 % annually in august , not 0.3 % as first estimated .
but prices fell month-on-month in america , pulling its inflation rate down to 1.7 % .
and european car sales have now risen for the 12th month running , although france still looks weak
the scottish referendum seems to be having an effect on markets beyond the uk .
spanish bonds have just strengthened to their higher level of the day after the panelbase poll put the no side ahead .
that pushed the yield , or interest rate , on 10-year spanish bonds down to 2.27 % , from 2.35 % yesterday .
that reflects speculation that catalonia 's independence movement could receive a boost if scotland breaks away from the uk .

documents.title: speaking of scotland
text: adam posen , a former member of the bank of england 's monetary policy committee , has hit out at fellow economist joseph stiglitz for being , in his view , too blase over the consequences of independence .
posen has blogged that the reality of independence is frightening '' .
he predicted that trade with ruk would suffer badly if scotland broke away , even if it used the pound .
leaving the united kingdom will be a huge blow to scottish commerce .
posen also argued that scotland 's role as an independent country would be particularly challenging as it would probably have to join the euro zone .
if scotland wishes to be part of the european union as a sovereign nation , however , by international treaty , it has to adopt the euro .
by adopting the euro , which has a germanic business cycle focus , the scottish economy will be repeatedly more out of sync with policy than in the united kingdom , promoting boom/busts .

but scotland would first have to get over the long list of economic and institutional hurdles required by treaty to be admitted to the euro area here 's the full piece : rebuttal to stiglitz on scotland : reality of independence is frightening
alberto nardelli ( @ albertonardelli ) final @ twitterid # indyref poll also has yes 48 % , no 52 % - that 's now 4 final polls in a row with the same numbers .
the pound has pushed a little higher , after a new scottish opinion poll also reported the no side leading the yes side by 4 percentage points .
steve collins ( @ tradedesk steve ) scottish vote : panelbase poll gives 'yes ' 48 % , 'no ' : 52 % it 's now up 0.5 % , or three-quarters of a cent , at $ 1.6351 .

the conservative party has fallen foul of the campaign to prevent wanton abuse of the y-axis on economic charts : joseph cotterill ( @ jsphctrl ) the y-axis has voted to secede from the uk , and was last seen attempting to join the eu more dramatic if you do n't start from zero , but also less accurate
putting today 's unemployment rate in some historical contect : uk unemployment rate since 1970

documents.title: analysts : weak us inflation takes pressure off the fed
text: the surprise drop in us inflation today means the federal reserve is less likely to drop its guidance that interest rates will remain low for a considerable time '' after its qe programme ends ( likely in october ) the fed will release a statement at 7pm bst ( 2pm eastern ) , which will be scrutinised for language changes .

paul dales of capital economics says : the further softening in us price pressures evident in august 's cpi data ease the pressure on the fed to amend its considerable time '' rate pledge at today 's policy meeting and rob carnell of ing reckons the fed will only make a small amendment : we suspect that any such changes will be small , most likely , a tweak to the text referring to the time after qe ends before the first rate hike .
perhaps a replacement of the word considerable '' , in this context .
aha , here 's a snap of the prime minister meeting workers at the weir minerals factory near yateley , where he described today 's unemployment figures as 'remarkable'.. dennis/afp/getty images
here 's the details of the surprise drop in us inflation : joseph weisenthal ( @ thestalwart ) look at that deflation in the energy space !

documents.title: us inflation lower than expected , as prices fall 0.2 % in august
text: just in : consumer prices in america have fallen for the first time in 16 months .
the monthly cpi index showed that prices fell by 0.2 % compared with july .
that dragged the annual us inflation date down to 1.7 % , surprising wall street which expected 1.9 % .
energy prices fell by 2.4 % in the month , including a 4.1 % slide in gasoline prices .
the fall in inflation helped to swell us real incomes during the month .
quite a comparison with the uk ( see chart at 1201pm ) joseph weisenthal ( @ thestalwart ) look who just got a big raise !
real earnings surge 0.4 % in august

documents.title: wages wo n't rise faster until talent is scarcer
text: the underlying reason that uk firms are n't offering inflation-busting pay rises is that they simply do n't have to .
despite the dramatic improvements in the jobless rate over the last year , employees do n't , yet , seem able to demand higher wages for their services .
that 's not true everywhere - construction firms , for example , have been reporting skills shortages , which inevitably puts more power in the hands of the workers .
but elsewhere , employers are still calling the shots , reflecting how the labour market has changed in recent decades .

our economics editor larry elliott writes : the first is that the old relationship whereby falling jobless numbers led to employers being forced to pay more for a shrinking pool of talent has broken down .
weaker trade unions , less collective bargaining , an increase in the percentage of the workforce that is part-time or self-employed : these are all factors keeping the lid on wage increases .
eventually , the traditional pattern will re-emerge .
at some point , unemployment will fall to a level that does lead to such intense competiton for labour that the balance of power in wage negotiations will shift .
but the current data suggests we are not at that point yet here 's larry 's full analysis : wages will not rise until employers have to compete for talent
back in the markets , the pound remains higher today ; currently up almost half a cent at $ 1.632 .
caroline hyde ( @ carolinehydetv ) £ / $ still holding on to gains ( +0.24 % ) as uk unemployment drops to lowest 6 yrs = 6.2 % .
august claimant count also lowest since 2008 = 2.9 %

the leader of the green party in england and wales , natalie bennett , blames the government for britain 's shrinking real wages : natalie bennett ( @ natalieben ) this government said it would make work pay : instead it 's made work pay a lot less : we need # jobstoliveon .

documents.title: david cameron : unemployment fall is 'remarkable '
text: a jobcentre plus in east london .

toscano/pa david cameron , whose mind must be whirling as the scottish vote nears , has welcomed the drop in unemployment and taken some credit for it : pa has the details : during a visit to weir minerals europe , a factory near fleet in hampshire , prime minister david cameron described the fall in people claiming unemployment benefit as really remarkable '' .
he added : we had a long-term economic plan , we stuck to that plan and you can see today that plan is working . ''
but mr cameron said they have not finished yet and have a lot more work to do '' .
that largely echoes george osborne 's tweets this mornings .
jonathan haynes ( @ jonathanhaynes ) yeah right : cameron reaffirms his intention not to resign in event of yes vote

the cbi , which represents british businesses , is dangling the prospect of wage increases up : with unemployment dropping , and wage settlements in larger firms starting to up , we expect to see average earnings growth begin to rise in time . ''
and this chart shows how average uk pay rises have lagged inflation for most months since the financial crisis struck .
jamie mcgeever ( @ reutersjamie ) uk unemployment lowest in 6 yrs .
but real earnings ( wage growth minus inflation ) now down 59 months in a row :
the tuc 's concerns about low wage growth are also shared by mark miller of the economist intelligence unit .
he reckons that it will deter the bank of england from raising interest rates in the next six months .
miller writes : in itself , the decline in unemployment of 146,000 during may-july 2014 compared with the previous quarter is clearly encouraging .
but further tightening in labour market conditions is still not being reflected in firmer pay growth .
latest average weekly earnings growth data ( both whole economy and excluding bonuses ) remain very subdued in historical terms .
this remains a key focus at the bank of england and accordingly , we do not envisage a first interest rate increase before the second quarter of 2015 . ''

documents.title: tuc : real wage crisis must be fixed
text: frances o'grady at the tuc conference in liverpool earlier this month .
thomas/rex union leaders are adamant that the labour market is not yet healed , despite seeing the headline unemployment rate hit a near-six year low .
frances o'grady , tuc general secretary , hammers home that workers have seen their pay packets eaten away by inflation over the last four years .
they are still suffering falling real wages today , given that regular pay rose by just 0.7 % year-on-year in may-july , when inflation was as high as 1.9 % .
o'grady says : last week the governor of the bank of england said the fall in real wages is the worst since the 1920s and today 's figures show it getting worse .
pay increases are less than half the rate of inflation , so living standards keep on falling .
more people are working , but growth based on more low-paid jobs is n't working for britain .
we need jobs that ensure everyone gets a fair share in the growing economy through real increases to their wages . `` .
and this issue is also concerning pwc , the consultancy group .
their chief economist , john hawksworth , says the shrinking real wages mean many people have missed out on the full benefit of the recovery .

here 's his take : today 's data shows that regular pay growth remains very subdued at just 0.7 % despite continued strong jobs growth , although the squeeze on real earnings has eased slightly with the recent fall in consumer price inflation to 1.5 % .
but to many workers facing a sixth consecutive year of declining real wages , the recovery may still seem to be something that is happening to other people .
weak pay growth appears to reflect increased labour supply in recent years , notably by older workers and immigrants , which has balanced the effect of increased labour demand .
more recently , it also reflects compositional effects due to the return to the workforce of some previously unemployed or inactive younger workers with relatively low pay and productivity levels .

documents.title: read the full story here
text: uk unemployment data , may-july 2014 here 's economics editor larry elliott on today 's jobs data : unemployment in the uk has dropped to its lowest level since the height of the 2008 financial crisis as a growing economy creates more part-time jobs , according to official figures .
both government measures of joblessness are falling , although data from the office for national statistics hinted that the improvement in the labour market could be slowing .
the labour force survey measure of unemployment , an internationally-agreed yardstick , declined by 146,000 in the three months to july , taking the total to 2.02 million .
over the past year , unemployment has dropped by 468,000 , the largest annual fall since the so-called lawson boom in 1988 .

the rate fell more sharply than expected , with the drop from 6.4 % to 6.2 % taking it to levels not seen for almost six years full story : uk unemployment rate falls to lowest level since 2008 financial crisis
the ons also has an 'unofficial ' stab at the unemployment rate for july alone , rather than for the may-july quarter .
and it shows that the jobless rate hit just 5.9 % , suggesting the headline rate will keep falling for the next couple of months .
chris giles ( @ chrisgiles ) unemployment falling like a stone .
single month rate ( july ) 5.9 %
duncan weldon ( @ duncanweldon ) strong labour market stats today - employment good , wages still well below inflation but up & hopeful signs on productivity .
rob wood , economist at berenberg , flags up that underemployment appears to have fallen : underemployment is falling too .
it is not just the headline unemployment figures that are showing significant change .
underemployment is one possible reason why wages have remained weak , but the signs are that it is declining quickly .
the proportion of part time workers who wanted but could not find a full-time job has fallen from 18.4 % to 16.5 % in the past year , for instanc

documents.title: labour : real pay still falling
text: labour mp stephen timms , the shadow employment minister , says that today 's fall in overall unemployment is welcome '' , but is also concerned that pay is still falling behind the cost of living ( see chart at 10.01am ) .
employment consultant dr john philpott reckons there are tentative signs in the latest figures that the balance between job creation and pay growth may have started to shift . ''
today 's data shows that the workforce expanded by 74,000 in may-july , the small increase in just over a year .
here 's an important point : the number of people who are n't in the uk labour market has increased , reversing a recent trend .
the ons reports that the economic inactivity rate '' in may-july was 22.1 % , up from 21.8 % in february to april .
that measure the percentage of the population who could potentially be in the workforce , but are not ( including full-time students ) .
that increase will have helped to drag down the jobless rate from 6.4 % to the near six-year low of 6.2 % .
as this chart shows , the economic inactivity rate had spiked when the financial crisis began , but had fallen pretty steadily since .
uk unemployment data , may-july 2014
the chancellor has been tweeting : george osborne ( @ george osborne ) new unemployment stats show claimant count fallen to under 1 million for 1st time since great recession .
# longtermeconomicplan is working george osborne ( @ george osborne ) today 's employment stats mark another step towards full employment .
but still much more to do .
will set out further plans this autumn george osborne ( @ george osborne ) unemployment in scotland is down to 6 % - below uk average .
scotland doing well as part of uk # bettertogether

documents.title: claimant count falls below one million
text: the claimant count has also hit a milestone .
the number of people receiving unemployment benefit fell to 966,500 in august , the first time it 's been below one million since 2008 .
uk claimant count , to august 2014
back to the uk unemployment data , and today 's data also shows that there has been a sharp rise in self-employment .
over the last year : the number of self-employed people working full-time increased by 225,000 to reach 3.24 million .
the number of self-employed people working part-time increased by 143,000 to reach 1.30 million .
the number of unpaid family workers increased by 13,000 to reach 119,000 .

documents.title: eurozone inflation rate revised up to +0.4 %
text: good news , the eurozone is n't quite as close to the quagmire of deflation as feared .
the eurozone inflation rate for august has been revised up , to +0.4 % annually , from 0.3 % , thanks to faster rising prices in the service sector .
that 's still alarmingly low , though .
eurozone inflation , revised , august 2014 frederik ducrozet ( @ fwred ) upward revision to eurozone hicp inflation , to 0.4 % yoy .
not that big a deal for now , but every bp is good to take .
and this chart shows that real wages are still falling , based on the 0.7 % rise in basic pay in today 's report..

documents.title: unemployment : the key charts
text: britain is now close to its highest ever employment rate , set in 1974.. men make up a narrow majority of the new entries to the labour market in the last year .

and most have taken on full-time jobs , unlike women , who are split between full-time and part-time positions : uk unemployment data , may-july 2014 and this shows how the us and uk labour markets have recovered over the last two years , while europe is struggling to bring down its record unemployment levels in the face of austerity .
uk unemployment data , may-july 2014

here 's the details of how the uk labour market changed over the last quarter : the number of people in employment increased by 74,000 ( to 30.61 million ) , the number of unemployed people fell by 146,000 ( to 2.02 million ) , and the number of people aged from 16 to 64 who were out of work but not seeking or available to work ( economically inactive ) increased by 114,000 ( to 8.93 million ) .

documents.title: uk earnings rise , but real wages still falling
text: there are signs that britain 's pay squeeze may be easing , but we 're not there yet .
the one reports that pay including bonuses for employees in great britain was 0.6 % higher than a year earlier in the may-july period .
a month ago , it shank by 0.2 % .
and regular pay , excluding bonuses , was 0.7 % higher than a year earlier .
that 's up from 0.6 % in april-june .
encouraging , but that still means that pay packets are shrinking in real terms .
inflation is currently running at 1.5 % .
the office for national statistics says : the main findings of this release are that employment continued to rise and unemployment continued to fall .
these changes continue the general direction of movement since late 2011/early 2012 .
the report is online here .
the number of people receiving unemployment benefit has fallen again ; down 37,000 in august .

documents.title: uk unemployment rate falls to 6.2 %
text: breaking : the uk unemployment rate has fallen to 6.2 % in the may-july quarter , down from 6.4 % a month ago .
that 's the lowest jobless rate since the september-november 2008 , the quarter when lehman brothers collapsed to trigger the biggest financial crisis in generations .
it 's a bigger fall than expected , showing that the labour market continues to recover .
the total number of people out of work fell by 146,000 in the quarter , to 2.109m .
lots more details and reaction to follow

documents.title: bank of england split 7-2 on rates again
text: boom , that 's 9.30am .
bank of england minutes first - they show that boe policymakers were split 7-2 on whether to raise interest rates again .
martin weale and ian mccafferty both wanted to raise rates to 0.75 % , but were outvoted .

analysts at dutch ing predict that today 's unemployment figures will show the jobless rate falling , and earnings up ( after dropping to just +0.6 % annually last month ) they say : we expect july unemployment to fall to 6.3 % and are looking for a rebound in july average weekly earnings . ''

documents.title: uk unemployment , a preamble
text: just 30 minutes until we get the uk labour market report .
there 's a few points to watch : whether the jobless rate fell in the may-july quarter , from 6.4 % a month ago .
whether the claimant count dipped in august did average annual earnings up , after hitting just +0.6 % a month ago , or -0.2 % including bonuses ?
whether more people become self-employed or are in part-time jobs but would rather be full time

speaking of scotland , our europe editor ian traynor has analysed how the prospect of scottish independence is causing head-scratching in brussels : here 's a flavour : a new regime is just taking shape in brussels , readying to run the european union for the next five years .

already it is clear that the three big items sitting in the in-trays for the new commission , the new parliament and the new president of the european council include what is known in brussels as the british question '' - whether the uk stays in the eu and on what terms .
the british question could be very soon superseded or joined by the scottish question '' - the riddle of scotland 's future in europe should it opt to go it alone and quit the uk .
the scottish question has senior eu officials and diplomats breaking out in a sweat .
british officials in brussels are besieged by anxious questions as to what is going to happen .
there are few clear answers to the scotland and europe dilemma .
only many more questions .
on the whole , brussels is praying for a no victory .

the two top outgoing officials in brussels , jose manuel barroso , head of the european commission , and herman van rompuy , president of the european council have both been less than generous when speaking of scotland 's eu prospects .

a yes to independence will take the eu into completely uncharted territory , legally and politically here 's the full story : eu officials , already vexed by 'british question ' must consider scotland too ian traynor ( @ traynorbrussels ) # scotland in europe .
a riddle inside a conundrum wrapped in an enigma , or something churchill said
shaun richards ( @ notayesmansecon ) a strong start for the uk pound £ today as it pushes above us $ 1.63 and towards euro 1.26 # gbp

and here 's why traders are protecting themselves against sterling volatility today : alberto nardelli ( @ albertonardelli ) the big question in the final round of # indyref polling is if any one poll will want to look too different compared to all the others .
the pound has risen a little this morning , gaining around 0.15 % against the us dollar and the euro to $ 1.63 and €1.258 .
but that is partly because the dollar is generally weaker , after the wsj predicted last night that the federal reserve will not hint at an earlier rate rise at today 's meeting .
and there are still signs of jitters over tomorrow 's scottish referendum in the city .
the cost of hedging against sharp swings in the british pound over the next 24 hours has doubled this morning , according to reuters data , as traders brace for volatility .

kit juckes of societe generale says the pound could be hit hard by a yes victory on friday morning : the latest opinion polls still put the no 's '' ahead in the scottish referendum , but the result will be extremely close .
the fx market remains long the pound and that is why gbp/usd has only bounced modestly .
the risk is greater to the downside on a 'yes ' than to the upside on a 'no ' .

documents.title: european markets rise on china liquidity reports
text: european stock markets are open , and the ftse 100 has up 16 points , or 0.25 % , in opening trading to 6806 .
the french and german markets both rose by 0.5 % , following gains on wall street last night .
traders are being encouraged by reports from beijing that the people 's bank of china is pumping $ 81bn of liquidity into the chinese banking system to prevent the economy slowing further .
speculation that the federal reserve will maintain its pledge to leave interest rates unchanged for a considerable time is also boosting shares .
ransquawk ( @ ransquawk ) o/n : pboc inject $ 81bln liquidity into china 's 5 largest banks , scottish 'no ' votes still in lead , hilsenrath says fed less hawkish

documents.title: european car industry records 12 months of rising sales
text: after some grim years , europe 's auto industry may finally be looking towards a better future .
industry body acea reports that sales rose by 5.6 % across europe in july and by 2.1 % in august .
that means 12 months of steady gains , with dealers shifting 6 % more cars so far this year than in 2013 .
european car sales , to august 2014 the recovery is still somewhat lopsided , though , with french demand notably weak : in july , france was the only major market to shrink ( -4.3 % ) .
elsewhere , growth ranged from 5.5 % in italy , 6.6 % in the uk , 6.8 % in germany and 11.1 % in spain , leading to a 5.6 % upturn in the region .
overall , 1,041,683 new cars were registered in the month .
in august , upturn prevailed across significant markets , resulting in an overall 2.1 % increase in the eu .
france , germany and italy registered a slight decrease ( -2.6 % , -0.4 % and -0.2 % respectively ) , while the other major markets expanded , registering 13.7 % more in spain and 9.4 % in the uk .

documents.title: sony predicts much bigger loss this year
text: bad news from sony - the japanese electronics giant has just warned that it will incur a much larger loss than previously forecast , and has suspended its dividend .
sony is taking a 180bn yen ( £ 1.03bn ) impairment charge on its mobile communications business .
it blamed tougher competition in the smartphone market .
sony had already predicted that it would make a loss this year , of around 50bn yen .
that 's now been hiked to 230bn yen .
it 's the latest in a string of bad news for sony , as bloomberg points out : chief executive officer kazuo hirai is struggling to revive sony through content , consoles and mobile devices .
the company has lost money in five of the last six years amid declining demand for televisions and compact cameras .
and fastft reckons sony is on track to have lost one trillion yen , or around £ 5bn , over the last five years .

documents.title: opening post
text: the bank of england : watching and waiting for the right time to raise rates .
turner/observer good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets , the world economy , business and the eurozone .
is britain 's labour market continuing to recover , and is the bank of england any closer to raising interest rates ?
we 'll get the answer to both questions this morning , with the latest unemployment report and the minutes of the boe 's most recent monetary policy committee meeting , both at 9.30am bst sharp .
economists predict that the uk jobless rate fell again in the three months to july , from 6.4 % to 6.3 % .
the number of people claiming unemployment benefit could also drop .
but for millions of workers , the big issue is whether wages are creeping back towards inflation ; the average earnings figures are likely to show that real pay is still falling .
the boe minutes , meanwhile , will show whether any more monetary policy committee members voted to raise interest rates in their meeting a fortnight ago .
last month , two mpc members plumped to hike , but were outvoted by the other seven .
it 's unlikely that a third hawk has appeared , but you never know in europe , the latest car sales figures have just been released showing that sales rose for the 12th month running .
more on that shortly and traders are nervously waiting for the federal reserve to end its monthly meeting tonight .
all the attention is whether the us central bank tweaks its forward guidance on monetary policy , and drop the pledge to keep interest rates unchanged for a considerable period '' .
not much in the corporate calendar , but high street chain jd sports have hiked their profit expectations after a decent start to the year .
peter hoskins ( @ peterhoskinssky ) share markets seen regaining ground at the open after yesterday 's losses .
financial bookies : ftse100 +15 , dax +40 , cac40 +23

bulletin.text: Pay increases are less than half the rate of inflation, so living standards keep on falling, says TUC chief.
The old wage/employment relationship has broken down.
UK jobless rate hits 6.2% <- coverage starts here.
Average earnings up but still lagging inflation.
Claimant count drops below one million.
